snp3.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
snp3.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

snp3.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sabhiyassa paribbājakassa purāṇasālohitāya devatāya pañhā uddiṭṭhā honti:
snp3.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time the wanderer Sabhiya had been presented with several questions by a deity who was a former blood relation, saying:

snp3.6:1.4.pli: “yo te, sabhiya, samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ime pañhe puṭṭho byākaroti tassa santike brahmacariyaṃ careyyāsī”ti.
snp3.6:1.4.eng: “Sabhiya, you should live the spiritual life with whatever ascetic or brahmin answers these questions.”

snp3.6:2.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako tassā devatāya santike te pañhe uggahetvā ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṃ—
snp3.6:2.1.eng: Then Sabhiya, after learning those questions in the presence of that deity, approached those ascetics and brahmins who led an order and a community, and taught a community, who were well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people. That is,

snp3.6:2.2.pli: pūraṇo kassapo makkhaligosālo ajito kesakambalo pakudho kaccāno sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto—
snp3.6:2.2.eng: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, Ajita of the hair blanket, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.

snp3.6:2.3.eng: And he asked them those questions,

snp3.6:2.4.pli: Te sabhiyena paribbājakena pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti;
snp3.6:2.4.eng: but they were stumped by them.

snp3.6:3.2.pli: “ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṃ—

snp3.6:3.4.pli: te mayā pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti,

snp3.6:3.6.eng: they questioned me in return on that matter.

snp3.6:3.7.eng: Why don’t I return to a lesser life so I can enjoy sensual pleasures?”

snp3.6:4.2.pli: “ayampi kho samaṇo gotamo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa;
snp3.6:4.2.eng: “This ascetic Gotama also leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people.

snp3.6:4.3.pli: yannūnāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyan”ti.
snp3.6:4.3.eng: Why don’t I ask him this question?”

snp3.6:5.2.pli: “yepi kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṃ—
snp3.6:5.2.eng: “Even those ascetics and brahmins who are elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; who are senior, long standing, long gone forth; who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community; who are well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people—that is

snp3.6:5.4.pli: tepi mayā pañhe puṭṭhā na sampāyanti,

snp3.6:5.5.pli: asampāyantā kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaronti, api ca maññevettha paṭipucchanti;
snp3.6:5.5.eng: They displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness, and even questioned me in return.

snp3.6:5.6.pli: kiṃ pana me samaṇo gotamo ime pañhe puṭṭho byākarissati.
snp3.6:5.6.eng: How can the ascetic Gotama possibly answer my questions,

snp3.6:5.7.pli: Samaṇo hi gotamo daharo ceva jātiyā, navo ca pabbajjāyā”ti.
snp3.6:5.7.eng: since he is so young in age and newly gone forth?”

snp3.6:6.2.pli: “samaṇo kho daharoti na uññātabbo na paribhotabbo.
snp3.6:6.2.eng: “An ascetic should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.

snp3.6:6.3.pli: Daharopi cesa samaṇo gotamo mahiddhiko hoti mahānubhāvo, yannūnāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe puccheyyan”ti.
snp3.6:6.3.eng: Though young, the ascetic Gotama has great psychic power and might. Why don’t I ask him this question?”

snp3.6:7.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
snp3.6:7.1.eng: Then Sabhiya set out for Rājagaha.

snp3.6:7.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ veḷuvanaṃ kalandakanivāpo, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
snp3.6:7.2.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he came to Rājagaha, the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. He went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

snp3.6:7.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
snp3.6:7.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

snp3.6:7.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi—
snp3.6:7.4.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp3.6:8.1.eng: “I’ve come full of  doubts and uncertainties,”

snp3.6:8.5.eng: Answer my questions in turn, <j>in accordance with the truth.”

snp3.6:9.4.eng: I shall solve them for you,

snp3.6:9.5.eng: answering your questions in turn, <j>in accordance with the truth.

snp3.6:11.3.pli: Yaṃ vatāhaṃ aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu okāsakammamattampi nālatthaṃ taṃ me idaṃ samaṇena gotamena okāsakammaṃ katan”ti.
snp3.6:11.3.eng: Where those other ascetics and brahmins didn’t even give me a chance, the Buddha has invited me.”

snp3.6:11.4.pli: Attamano pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi—
snp3.6:11.4.eng: Uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, he asked this question.

snp3.6:12.1.eng: “What must one attain to be called a mendicant?”

snp3.6:12.3.eng: “How is one ‘gentle’, how said to be ‘tamed’?

snp3.6:12.4.eng: How is one declared to be ‘awakened’?

snp3.6:12.5.eng: May the Buddha please answer my question.”

snp3.6:13.1.eng: “When by the path they have walked themselves,”

snp3.6:13.4.eng: giving up desire for existence or nonexistence,

snp3.6:13.5.eng: their journey complete, their rebirths ended: <j>that is a mendicant.

snp3.6:14.2.eng: they don’t harm anyone in the world.

snp3.6:14.3.eng: An ascetic who has crossed over, unclouded,

snp3.6:14.4.pli: Ussadā yassa na santi sorato so.
snp3.6:14.4.eng: who has no pretensions, is gentle.

snp3.6:15.2.eng: inside and out in the whole world.

snp3.6:15.3.eng: Having pierced through this world and the next,

snp3.6:16.1.eng: They have examined the eons in their entirety,
snp3.6:16.1.comm: The Commentary allows kappa in the sense of both “mental activity” and “eon” here. The context in this verse suggests it is about the eons of transmigration.

snp3.6:16.2.eng: and both sides of transmigration—<j>passing away and rebirth.

snp3.6:16.4.eng: the one they call ‘awakened’ has attained <j>the end of rebirth.”

snp3.6:17.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā attamano pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi—
snp3.6:17.1.eng: And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya asked another question:

snp3.6:18.1.eng: “What must one attain to be called ‘brahmin’?”

snp3.6:18.3.eng: “Why is one an ‘ascetic’, and how a ‘bathed initiate’?

snp3.6:18.4.eng: How is one declared to be a ‘giant’?

snp3.6:18.5.eng: May the Buddha please answer my question.”

snp3.6:19.5.comm: Commentary glosses brahmā with brāhmaṇa, which is required by the sense.

snp3.6:20.1.eng: An assuaged one who has given up good and evil,

snp3.6:20.2.eng: stainless, understanding this world and the next,

snp3.6:21.1.eng: Having washed off all bad things

snp3.6:21.2.eng: inside and out in the whole world,

snp3.6:21.3.eng: among gods and humans bound to creations,

snp3.6:21.4.eng: the one they call ‘washed’ does not return to creation.

snp3.6:22.1.eng: They do nothing monstrous at all in the world,

snp3.6:23.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi—
snp3.6:23.1.eng: And then Sabhiya asked another question:

snp3.6:24.1.eng: “Who is a ‘field-victor’ according to the Buddhas?”
snp3.6:24.1.comm: I think Norman’s reconstruction of this to root ñā (followed by Bodhi) is too speculative. The word makes fine sense as is, and is more metaphorically connected with the sense of khetta.

snp3.6:24.3.eng: “Why is one ‘skillful’, and how ‘a wise scholar’?

snp3.6:24.4.eng: How is one declared to be a ‘sage’?

snp3.6:24.5.eng: May the Buddha please answer my question.”

snp3.6:25.1.eng: “They are victors on the fields of deeds in their entirety,”
snp3.6:25.1.comm: Reading vijeyya; both viceyya and vijeyya are accepted in the commentary. The “fields” are the “fields of deeds” (AN 3.77:2.3).

snp3.6:25.3.eng: “the fields of gods, humans, and divinitiess;

snp3.6:25.4.eng: released from the root bondage to all fields:

snp3.6:26.1.eng: They have examined the coffers in their entirety,

snp3.6:26.2.eng: the coffers of gods, humans, and divinitiess;

snp3.6:26.3.eng: released from the root bondage to all coffers:

snp3.6:27.1.comm: Paṇḍarāni means not “senses” per commentary, but is a synonym for suddhi in the next line. A true paṇḍita is pure both inside and out.

snp3.6:27.2.eng: both inside and out; understanding purity,

snp3.6:27.3.eng: they have left dark and bright behind:

snp3.6:27.4.eng: one such is rightly called ‘a wise scholar’.”

snp3.6:28.1.eng: Understanding the nature of the bad and the good

snp3.6:28.2.eng: inside and out in the whole world;

snp3.6:28.3.eng: one worthy of honor by gods and humans,

snp3.6:28.4.eng: who has escaped from the net and the chain: that is a sage.”

snp3.6:29.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi—
snp3.6:29.1.eng: And then Sabhiya asked another question:

snp3.6:30.1.eng: “What must one attain <j>to be called ‘knowledge master’?”

snp3.6:30.3.eng: “Why is one ‘studied’, and how is one ‘heroic’?

snp3.6:30.5.eng: May the Buddha please answer my question.”

snp3.6:31.1.eng: “They have examined knowledges in their entirety,”

snp3.6:31.3.eng: “those that are current among ascetics and brahmins;

snp3.6:31.4.eng: rid of greed for all feelings,

snp3.6:31.5.eng: having left all knowledges behind: <j>that is a knowledge master.

snp3.6:32.1.eng: Having studied proliferation and name & form

snp3.6:32.2.eng: inside and out—the root of disease;

snp3.6:32.3.eng: released from the root bondage to all disease:

snp3.6:33.2.eng: heroic, he escapes from the suffering of hell;
snp3.6:33.2.comm: The commentary’s “abode of energy” for viriyavāso doesn’t sound right to me, though followed by Bodhi and Norman. I read viriyavā so.

snp3.6:34.2.eng: the root of clinging inside and out;

snp3.6:34.3.eng: released from the root bondage to all clinging:

snp3.6:35.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako …pe… bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi—
snp3.6:35.1.eng: And then Sabhiya asked another question:

snp3.6:36.1.eng: “What must one attain to be called ‘scholar’?”

snp3.6:36.3.eng: “Why is one ‘noble’, and how is one ‘well conducted’?

snp3.6:36.5.eng: May the Buddha please answer my question.”

snp3.6:37.1.comm: The absolutives sutvā and abhiññāya apply to their respective following accusatives sabbadhammaṁ and sāvajjānavajjaṁ.

snp3.6:37.3.eng: “and has known for themselves what in the world <j>is blameworthy and blameless;

snp3.6:38.1.eng: Having cut off defilements and clingings,
snp3.6:38.1.comm: Here ālaya (“clinging”) is punned with ariya (“noble”). See MN 39:28.1.

snp3.6:38.2.eng: being wise, they enter no womb.

snp3.6:38.3.eng: They’ve cast aside the bog of the three perceptions,
snp3.6:38.3.comm: The three perceptions are sensuality, malice, and cruelty. Since paṅka is a stock metaphor for kāma, it seems we should read “the bog of the three perceptions” rather than “the three perceptions and the bog”.

snp3.6:38.4.eng: the one they call ‘noble’ does not return to creation.

snp3.6:39.1.eng: One here who is accomplished <j>and skillful in all forms of good conduct;
snp3.6:39.1.comm: The syntax reads more cleanly if the nominatives in this line and the next are read together; and the clauses following sabb- are likewise read in parallel.

snp3.6:39.3.eng: everywhere not stuck, freed in mind,

snp3.6:39.4.pli: Paṭighā yassa na santi caraṇavā so.
snp3.6:39.4.eng: who has no repulsion: they are ‘well-conducted’.

snp3.6:40.2.eng: having banished any deed that results in suffering,

snp3.6:40.3.eng: deceit and conceit, as well as greed and anger,

snp3.6:40.5.eng: They have made a limit on name & form;
snp3.6:40.5.comm: Pariyanta means “limit, boundary”. An arahant still has name & form, but only until the end of their life.

snp3.6:40.6.eng: the one they call a ‘wanderer’ <j>has reached their destination.”
snp3.6:40.6.comm: I think pattipatta is a play on words here.

snp3.6:41.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā attamano pamudito udaggo pītisomanassajāto uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
snp3.6:41.1.eng: And then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, uplifted and elated, full of rapture and happiness, Sabhiya got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

snp3.6:42.1.eng: “O one of vast wisdom, <j>there are three & sixty opinions
snp3.6:42.1.comm: These are the sixty-two views of the Brahmajālasutta (DN 1). The view of self underlies them all (SN 41.3:4.13), and according to the commentary it is here included as the sixty-third. Numbered as “sixty” at SN 8.2:5.1 = Thag 21.1:9.1.

snp3.6:42.2.eng: based on the doctrines of ascetics:

snp3.6:42.3.eng: they are expressions of perception, <j>based on perception.

snp3.6:42.4.eng: Having dispelled them all, <j>you passed over the dark flood.

snp3.6:43.1.eng: You have gone to the end, gone beyond suffering,

snp3.6:43.2.eng: you are perfected, a fully awakened Buddha; <j>I think you have ended defilements.

snp3.6:43.4.eng: ender of suffering—you brought me across!

snp3.6:44.2.eng: you brought me beyond doubt—homage to you!

snp3.6:44.3.eng: A sage, accomplished in the ways of sagacity,

snp3.6:44.4.eng: you are gentle, not hardhearted, O Kinsman of the Sun.
snp3.6:44.4.comm: Oddly, at AN 5.38:5.4 we find sorata with sakhila in a similar sense to akhila here.

snp3.6:45.1.eng: Any doubts that I once had,

snp3.6:45.2.eng: you have answered for me, O Clear-eyed One.

snp3.6:45.3.eng: Clearly you are a sage, an Awakened One,

snp3.6:45.4.eng: there are no hindrances in you.

snp3.6:46.2.eng: is blown away and mown down.

snp3.6:47.1.eng: O giant among giants, O great hero,

snp3.6:47.4.comm: A rare Pali reference to the legendary sages Nārada and his nephew Parvata, whose story is in the Viṣṇu Purāṇa.

snp3.6:48.2.eng: Homage to you, supreme among men!

snp3.6:48.3.eng: In the world with its gods,

snp3.6:49.1.eng: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,

snp3.6:49.2.eng: you are the sage who has overcome Māra;

snp3.6:49.3.eng: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,

snp3.6:49.4.eng: you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.

snp3.6:50.3.eng: you are a lion, free of grasping,

snp3.6:50.4.eng: with fear and dread given up.

snp3.6:51.2.eng: to which water does not stick,

snp3.6:51.5.eng: Stretch out your feet, great hero:

snp3.6:52.1.pli: Atha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.6:52.1.eng: Then the wanderer Sabhiya bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said,

snp3.6:52.3.pli: esāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca;
snp3.6:52.3.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

snp3.6:52.4.pli: labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
snp3.6:52.4.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

snp3.6:53.1.pli: “Yo kho, sabhiya, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati; catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
snp3.6:53.1.eng: “Sabhiya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.

snp3.6:53.2.eng: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”

snp3.6:54.1.pli: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṃ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya, ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi; catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
snp3.6:54.1.eng: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

snp3.6:54.2.pli: Alattha kho sabhiyo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ alattha upasampadaṃ …pe…
snp3.6:54.2.eng: And the wanderer Sabhiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

snp3.6:54.3.pli: aññataro kho panāyasmā sabhiyo arahataṃ ahosīti.
snp3.6:54.3.eng: And Venerable Sabhiya became one of the perfected.
